{"uri": "2024-07-417772749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:51:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:51:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:26:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.wxow.com/news/minnesota-news/bidens-candidacy-faces-new-peril-as-pelosi-clooney-and-more-democrats-weigh-in/article_c1d86faa-ccfa-54b9-a0ed-4c1878628e71.html", "title": "Biden's candidacy faces new peril as Pelosi, Clooney and more Democrats weigh in", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden's imperiled re-election campaign hit new trouble Wednesday as House Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi said merely \"it's up to the president to decide\" if he should stay in the race, celebrity donor George Clooney said he should not run and Democratic senators and lawmakers expressed fresh fear about his ability to beat Republican Donald Trump.\n\nThe sudden flurry of grave pronouncements despite Biden's determined insistence he is not leaving the 2024 race put on public display just how unsettled the question remains among prominent Democrats. On Capitol Hill, an eighth House Democrat, Rep. Pat Ryan of New York, publicly asked Biden to step aside.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC rather than declaring Biden should stay in. Though he's said repeatedly that he's made his decision, she said, \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nIt's a crucial moment for the president and his party, as Democrats consider what was once unthinkable -- having the incumbent Biden step aside, just weeks before the Democratic National Convention that is on track to nominate him as their candidate for reelection.\n\nBiden is hosting world leaders in Washington for the NATO summit this week with a crowded schedule of formal meetings, sideline chats and long diplomatic dinners. He faces his next public test Thursday when he is scheduled to hold a news conference that many are watching for signs of his abilities.\n\nTo be sure, Biden maintains strong support from key corners of his coalition, particularly the Congressional Black Caucus on Capitol Hill, whose leadership was instrumental in ushering the president to victory in 2020 and is standing by him as the country's best choice to defeat Trump again in 2024.\n\n\"At this moment, the stakes are too high and we have to focus,\" Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota told The Associated Press on Tuesday, saying Democrats are \"losing ground\" the longer they fight over Biden's candidacy. \"Democracy is on the line. Everything we value as Democrats, as a country, is on the line, and we have to stop being distracted.\"\n\nPelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Biden's wounded candidacy, her comments viewed as important for the party's direction as members weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House speaker and proximity to Biden as a trusted longtime ally of his generation, Pelosi is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the president's thinking.\n\nThe lack of a full statement from Pelosi backing Biden's continued campaign is what lawmakers are likely to hear most clearly. Her remarks came moments before actor Clooney, who had just hosted a glitzy Hollywood fundraiser for the president last month, said in a New York Times op-ed that the Biden he saw three weeks ago wasn't the Joe Biden of 2020. \"He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, a Democrat from Colorado, spoke forcefully late Tuesday about the danger of a second Trump presidency and said it's for the president \"to consider\" the options.\n\nStopping just short of calling for Biden to drop out, Bennet said on CNN what he told his colleagues in private - that he believes Trump \"is on track to win this election -- and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House.\"\n\nBennet said, \"It's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country.\"\n\nAnother Democrat, Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, said Wednesday he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden winning the election, which he called existential for the country.\n\n\"We have to reach a conclusion as soon as possible,\" Blumenthal said on CNN.\n\nDemocrats have been reeling over the question of whether to continue backing Biden after his poor showing in the June 27 presidential debate with Trump and his campaign's lackluster response to their pleas that Biden, at 81, show voters he is up for another four-year term.\n\nBiden and his campaign are working more intently now to shore up support, and the president met with labor leaders Wednesday, relying on the unions to help make the case that his record in office matters more than his age.\n\nWith the executive council of the AFL-CIO, America's largest federation of trade unions, Biden told the crowd that even Wall Street was acknowledging the power of unions, as he once again articulated his vision for an economy built \"from the bottom up and middle out.\"\n\n\"I said I'm going to be the most pro-union president in American history,\" Biden told the cheering crowd. \"Well guess what? I am.\"\n\nWhile more House Democrats have publicly called on Biden to end his candidacy, no Senate Democrats have gone that far. Bennet was among three Democratic senators, including Jon Tester of Montana and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who spoke up during a private lunch Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nPelosi of California said Biden \"has been a great president\" who is beloved and respected by House Democrats.\n\nThe Californian said she watched as he delivered a forceful speech at the NATO summit on Tuesday, and recounted his many accomplishments.\n\nWhile foreign leaders are in Washington this week and Biden is on the world stage hosting the event at a critical time in foreign affairs, Pelosi encouraged Democrats \"let's just hold off\" with any announcements about his campaign.\n\n\"Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see,\" she said, how it goes \"this week.\"\n\n--\n\nAssociated Press writer Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": It's a moral question about the future of our country.'\n\nPresident Joe Biden's imperiled re-election campaign hit new trouble Wednesday as House Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi said merely \"it's up to the President to decide\" if he should stay in the race, celebrity donor George Clooney said he should not run and Democratic Senators and lawmakers expressed fresh fear about his ability to beat Republican Donald Trump.\n\nThe sudden flurry of grave pronouncements despite Biden's determined insistence he is not leaving the 2024 race put on public display just how unsettled the question remains among prominent Democrats. On Capitol Hill, an eighth House Democrat, U.S. Rep. Pat Ryan of New York, publicly asked Biden to step aside.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC rather than declaring Biden should stay in. Though he's said repeatedly that he's made his decision, she said, \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nIt's a crucial moment for the President and his party, as Democrats consider what was once unthinkable -- having the incumbent Biden step aside, just weeks before the Democratic National Convention that is on track to nominate him as their candidate for re-election.\n\nBiden is hosting world leaders in Washington for the NATO summit this week with a crowded schedule of formal meetings, sideline chats and long diplomatic dinners. He faces his next public test Thursday when he is scheduled to hold a news conference that many are watching for signs of his abilities.\n\nTo be sure, Biden maintains strong support from key corners of his coalition, particularly the Congressional Black Caucus on Capitol Hill, whose leadership was instrumental in ushering the President to victory in 2020 and is standing by him as the country's best choice to defeat Trump again in 2024.\n\nPelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Biden's wounded candidacy, her comments viewed as important for the party's direction as members weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House Speaker and proximity to Biden as a trusted longtime ally of his generation, Pelosi is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the President's thinking.\n\nThe lack of a full statement from Pelosi backing Biden's continued campaign is what lawmakers are likely to hear most clearly. Her remarks came moments before actor Clooney, who had just hosted a glitzy Hollywood fundraiser for the President last month, said in a New York Times op-ed that the Biden he saw three weeks ago wasn't the Joe Biden of 2020. \"He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nU.S. Sen. Michael Bennet, a Democrat from Colorado, spoke forcefully late Tuesday about the danger of a second Trump presidency and said it's for the President \"to consider\" the options.\n\nStopping just short of calling for Biden to drop out, Bennet said on CNN what he told his colleagues in private -- that he believes Trump \"is on track to win this election -- and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House.\"\n\nBennet said, \"It's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country.\"\n\nAnother Democrat, U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, said Wednesday he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden winning the election, which he called existential for the country.\n\n\"We have to reach a conclusion as soon as possible,\" Blumenthal said on CNN.\n\nDemocrats have been reeling over the question of whether to continue backing Biden after his poor showing in the June 27 presidential debate with Trump and his campaign's lackluster response to their pleas that Biden, at 81, show voters he is up for another four-year term.\n\nBiden and his campaign are working more intently now to shore up support, and the President met with labor leaders Wednesday, relying on the unions to help make the case that his record in office matters more than his age.\n\nWith the executive council of the AFL-CIO, America's largest federation of trade unions, Biden told the crowd that even Wall Street was acknowledging the power of unions, as he once again articulated his vision for an economy built \"from the bottom up and middle out.\"\n\n\"I said I'm going to be the most pro-union president in American history,\" Biden told the cheering crowd. \"Well guess what? I am.\"\n\nWhile more House Democrats have publicly called on Biden to end his candidacy, no Senate Democrats have gone that far. Bennet was among three Democratic Senators, including Jon Tester of Montana and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who spoke up during a private lunch Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nPelosi of California said Biden \"has been a great President\" who is beloved and respected by House Democrats.\n\nThe Californian said she watched as he delivered a forceful speech at the NATO summit on Tuesday, and recounted his many accomplishments.\n\nWhile foreign leaders are in Washington this week and Biden is on the world stage hosting the event at a critical time in foreign affairs, Pelosi encouraged Democrats \"let's just hold off\" with any announcements about his campaign.\n\n\"Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see,\" she said, how it goes \"this week.\"\n\n___\n\nRepublished with permission of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "floridapolitics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. {"uri": "2024-07-417666296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:01:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:01:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:49:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/nancy-pelosi-urges-president-joe-biden-to-make-decision-soon-on-continuation-in-race-says-time-is-limited/", "title": "\"Nancy Pelosi Urges President Joe Biden to Make Decision Soon on Continuation in Race, says Time is Limited\" - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, appearing on MSNBC on Wednesday morning, declined to directly answer when asked if President Joe Biden had her support as he seeks reelection amid debate between Democrats on his viability as a candidate.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he is going to run,\" Pelosi told \"Morning Joe\" co-host Jonathan Lemire. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\n\"I think overwhelming support of the caucus -- it's not for me to say, I'm not the head of the caucus anymore -- but, he's beloved, he is respected and people want him to make that decision,\" Pelosi added.\n\nBiden, in a defiant statement to congressional Democrats on Monday, has said he's \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race to the end.\n\nLemire followed up by asking Pelosi directly, \"Do you want him to run?\"\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi responded. \"And that is the way it is. Whatever he decides to go with.\"\n\n\"I said to everyone -- let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week. But I am very proud of the president,\" Pelosi added.\n\nThe Biden campaign's response to Pelosi's comments was, \"He's running.\"\n\nPelosi led House Democrats for the first two years of the Biden administration, helping pass some of his signature policy achievements such as the bipartisan infrastructure law and gun safety legislation. As a Democratic leader who has worked closely with Biden, Pelosi's thoughts on the president's ability to hold the office could carry a lot of weight in an election year where Biden's rematch with former President Donald Trump is expected to be a close contest.\n\nABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos, in Biden's first post-debate television interview, repeatedly pressed the president what he would do if Democratic leaders such as Chuck Schumer, Hakeem Jeffries and Pelosi were to tell him they were worried his presence in the race would impact the party's chances of controlling the House and Senate.\n\nMORE | Biden dismisses diminishing poll numbers, low approval rating after debate\n\nBiden told Stephanopoulos, \"Well, it's, like, they're not gonna do that.\"\n\nSchumer on Tuesday simply told reporters multiple times, \"I'm with Joe\" -- but declined to engage in broader questions on Biden's path forward.\n\nJeffries, who earlier this week said he still supported Biden and that his position remained unchanged, huddled behind closed doors on Tuesday with House Democrats to discuss Biden's path forward.\n\nSome members described the meeting as \"rough\" and sobering, according to multiple participants. Others described feeling powerless to change course amid Biden's defiance.\n\nAfter the meeting, a seventh House Democrat -- New Jersey's Mikie Sherrill -- publicly called on Biden to exit the race.\n\nMORE | House Democrats huddle behind closed doors amid debate over Biden's path forward\n\nBut others, including Rep. Jerry Nadler and Rep. Jim Clyburn, expressed support for Biden.\n\n\"Right now, President Biden is the nominee. We support the Democratic nominee,\" Rep. Pete Aguilar, chair of the House Democratic Caucus, said at a press conference.\n\nSenate Democrats also met for their own conference meeting on Tuesday.\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, during an interview with CNN, said in the meeting he expressed to colleagues his belief that Biden will not defeat Trump this November.\n\n\"Donald Trump is on track, I think to win this election and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House,\" Bennet said. \"For me, this is not a question about polling, it's not a question about politics, it's a moral question about the future of our country and I think it's critically important for us to come to grips with what we face if together we put this country on the path of electing Donald Trump again.\"\n\nMultiple sources confirmed to ABC that Sens. Jon Tester and Sherrod Brown conveyed similar concerns about Biden's ability to win during the meeting. Brown and Tester are both facing difficult reelection campaigns of their own this cycle.\n\nThe Biden campaign pushed back on Bennet's comments, saying the race was always going to be close and is {"uri": "2024-07-417780326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:59:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:59:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:26:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/bidens-candidacy-faces-new-peril-as-pelosi-clooney-and-more-democrats-weigh-in/article_aae9bad4-bb15-5106-a69f-f68a4f3cbdf9.html", "title": "Biden's candidacy faces new peril as Pelosi, Clooney and more Democrats weigh in", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden's imperiled re-election campaign hit new trouble Wednesday as House Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi said merely \"it's up to the president to decide\" if he should stay in the race, celebrity donor George Clooney said he should not run and Democratic senators and lawmakers expressed fresh fear about his ability to beat Republican Donald Trump.\n\nThe sudden flurry of grave pronouncements despite Biden's determined insistence he is not leaving the 2024 race put on public display just how unsettled the question remains among prominent Democrats. On Capitol Hill, an eighth House Democrat, Rep. Pat Ryan of New York, publicly asked Biden to step aside.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC rather than declaring Biden should stay in. Though he's said repeatedly that he's made his decision, she said, \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nIt's a crucial moment for the president and his party, as Democrats consider what was once unthinkable -- having the incumbent Biden step aside, just weeks before the Democratic National Convention that is on track to nominate him as their candidate for reelection.\n\nBiden is hosting world leaders in Washington for the NATO summit this week with a crowded schedule of formal meetings, sideline chats and long diplomatic dinners. He faces his next public test Thursday when he is scheduled to hold a news conference that many are watching for signs of his abilities.\n\nTo be sure, Biden maintains strong support from key corners of his coalition, particularly the Congressional Black Caucus on Capitol Hill, whose leadership was instrumental in ushering the president to victory in 2020 and is standing by him as the country's best choice to defeat Trump again in 2024.\n\n\"At this moment, the stakes are too high and we have to focus,\" Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota told The Associated Press on Tuesday, saying Democrats are \"losing ground\" the longer they fight over Biden's candidacy. \"Democracy is on the line. Everything we value as Democrats, as a country, is on the line, and we have to stop being distracted.\"\n\nPelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Biden's wounded candidacy, her comments viewed as important for the party's direction as members weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House speaker and proximity to Biden as a trusted longtime ally of his generation, Pelosi is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the president's thinking.\n\nThe lack of a full statement from Pelosi backing Biden's continued campaign is what lawmakers are likely to hear most clearly. Her remarks came moments before actor Clooney, who had just hosted a glitzy Hollywood fundraiser for the president last month, said in a New York Times op-ed that the Biden he saw three weeks ago wasn't the Joe Biden of 2020. \"He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, a Democrat from Colorado, spoke forcefully late Tuesday about the danger of a second Trump presidency and said it's for the president \"to consider\" the options.\n\nStopping just short of calling for Biden to drop out, Bennet said on CNN what he told his colleagues in private - that he believes Trump \"is on track to win this election -- and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House.\"\n\nBennet said, \"It's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country.\"\n\nAnother Democrat, Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, said Wednesday he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden winning the election, which he called existential for the country.\n\n\"We have to reach a conclusion as soon as possible,\" Blumenthal said on CNN.\n\nDemocrats have been reeling over the question of whether to continue backing Biden after his poor showing in the June 27 presidential debate with Trump and his campaign's lackluster response to their pleas that Biden, at 81, show voters he is up for another four-year term.\n\nBiden and his campaign are working more intently now to shore up support, and the president met with labor leaders Wednesday, relying on the unions to help make the case that his record in office matters more than his age.\n\nWith the executive council of the AFL-CIO, America's largest federation of trade unions, Biden told the crowd that even Wall Street was acknowledging the power of unions, as he once again articulated his vision for an economy built \"from the bottom up and middle out.\"\n\n\"I said I'm going to be the most pro-union president in American history,\" Biden told the cheering crowd. \"Well guess what? I am.\"\n\nWhile more House Democrats have publicly called on Biden to end his candidacy, no Senate Democrats have gone that far. Bennet was among three Democratic senators, including Jon Tester of Montana and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who spoke up during a private lunch Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nPelosi of California said Biden \"has been a great president\" who is beloved and respected by House Democrats.\n\nThe Californian said she watched as he delivered a forceful speech at the NATO summit on Tuesday, and recounted his many accomplishments.\n\nWhile foreign leaders are in Washington this week and Biden is on the world stage hosting the event at a critical time in foreign affairs, Pelosi encouraged Democrats \"let's just hold off\" with any announcements about his campaign.\n\n\"Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see,\" she said, how it goes \"this week.\"\n\n--\n\nAssociated Press writer Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this {"uri": "8219288419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:34:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:34:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:34:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/10/pelosi-urges-biden-to-make-decision-on-race-despite-his-insistence-he-will-stay/", "title": "Pelosi urges Biden to make decision on race, despite his insistence he will stay", "body": "President Joe Biden escorts Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., from Marine One to attend a fundraiser in San Francisco on Wednesday Feb. 21. Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press file\n\nIn a Wednesday morning interview, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., repeatedly urged President Biden to decide whether to stay in the presidential race, despite the president's insistence that he should remain at the top of the Democratic ticket.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he is going to run. We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe.\" \" ... He is beloved, he is respected, and people want him to make that decision.\"\n\nBiden so far has been adamant that he should continue running for reelection, amid increasingly public concerns within the party about his candidacy after his halting performance against Donald Trump in the first debate of the contest last month. Biden has insisted that he is the best person to beat Trump, who he warned would usher in a radical right-wing agenda if allowed to return to the White House. On Wednesday, Biden has a full slate of events as host of this week's NATO summit in Washington, where dozens of world leaders are discussing, among other issues, how to \"Trump-proof\" the alliance should the former president be reelected.\n\nSince the debate, Biden has held campaign rallies, sat for an interview with ABC News, sent a lengthy letter to congressional lawmakers and agreed to hold a news conference Thursday, all in the hope of quelling doubts about his ability to serve a second term. Biden and his team also have met with key party leaders who have voiced strong support for his candidacy - including New York's Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and Senate Majority Leader Charles E. Schumer, as well as members of the Congressional Black Caucus.\n\nBut Pelosi's remarks in her TV appearance Wednesday suggested that Biden had yet to make a final decision about whether to continue running, and dissent within the party has continued to trickle out. Pressed on whether she wanted him to stay in the race, Pelosi said: \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do. And that's - that's the way it is. Whatever he decides, we go with.\"\n\nPelosi also implied that she had told Democratic lawmakers to refrain from voicing any opinions about Biden's candidacy until after the NATO summit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Over 30 heads of state are here. ... It means [Biden is] orchestrating the discussion and setting the agenda, and he's doing so magnificently,\" Pelosi said. \"And I've said to everyone - let's just hold off whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week. But I'm very proud of the president.\"\n\nLater Wednesday, Pelosi told a CBS News reporter that she thought Biden was \"great\" and that she never said Biden should \"reconsider\" his decision.\n\nIn an email Wednesday, Pelosi spokesman Ian Krager said: \"Speaker Pelosi fully supports whatever President Biden decides to do. We must turn our attention to why this race is so important: Donald Trump would be a disaster for our country and our democracy.\"\n\nDemocratic lawmakers remain divided on Biden - and have certainly not remained quiet about their opinions on the president. So far, about a dozen Democratic lawmakers have called on Biden to drop out of the 2024 race. Rep. Pat Ryan, D-N.Y., a moderate who represents a swing district, told the New York Times on Wednesday that he would be \"doing a grave disservice\" if he said Biden was the best Democratic candidate.\n\n\"For the good of our country, for my two young kids, I'm asking Joe Biden to step aside in the upcoming election and deliver on the promise to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders,\" Ryan told the Times.\n\nLate Tuesday, Sen. Michael Bennet, D-Colo., told CNN that Trump was on track to win the election \"by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House\" if Biden remained in the race.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"For me, this isn't a question about polling; it's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country,\" Bennet said. \"It's critically important for us to come to grips with what we face, if together, we put this country on the path of electing Donald Trump again.\"\n\nAsked to respond to Bennet's comments, Biden campaign spokesman Kevin Munoz said: \"No one is more committed to defeating Donald Trump and defending our democracy than Joe Biden, and few know better than Joe Biden the importance of showing up and campaigning to earn the support of voters. This was always going to be a close race.\"\n\nActor and filmmaker George Clooney, a longtime Biden supporter who has helped raise funds for the campaign, including in a major event last month in Los Angeles, published a guest op-ed in the New York Times on Wednesday calling for a new Democratic nominee.\n\n\"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010,\" Clooney wrote. \"He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nCNN political commentator Kate Bedingfield, who served as communications director for Biden's 2020 campaign and in the White House, suggested Wednesday that voters want to see data supporting the idea that Biden can win in November.\n\n\"I know firsthand better than almost anyone how smart the Biden team is about data and about ignoring the noise. They are right that the game here is to convince voters, not pundits,\" Bedingfield wrote on X. \"But when the battle over the public data is so overwhelmingly negative, it's a good moment to put forward your theory of the case. If they have data that supports the path to victory that they see, they should put it out there now and help people who badly want to beat Trump rally around it. People want to see the path.\"\n\nLiz Goodwin and Maeve Reston contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines George Clooney and the growing celebrity revolt against {"uri": "2024-07-417574694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:37:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:37:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:27:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/the-latest-biden-facing-pressure-over-age-19564921.php", "title": "The Latest: Biden, facing pressure over age, meets with labor groups; Trump revels in Biden turmoil", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden, facing pressure from within his own party to abandon his reelection campaign, is set to meet Wednesday with the executive council of the AFL-CIO, America's largest federation of trade unions as he tries to make the case that his record in office matters more than his age. The 81-year-old Biden is also taking part in the NATO summit and looking to use the organization's 75th anniversary meeting as a way to spotlight support for Ukraine in its fight against Russia and to reset his stumbling campaign.\n\nBiden has been under intense scrutiny since his disastrous debate performance, putting pressure on a White House that until recently had been marked by discipline and loyalty.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump has been reveling in the turmoil surrounding the Biden campaign and pressure from Biden's party to step down. Trump is also expected to soon announce his Republican running mate.\n\nSpeaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi stopped short of saying President Joe Biden should continue his re-election campaign, saying \"it's up to the president to decide\" if he's going to run.\n\n\"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short,\" Pelosi said early Wednesday on MSNBC.\n\nPressed on whether That was the question circulating after an early Wednesday appearance on MSNBC. It wasn't just Republicans pondering the thought either.\n\nAppearing on \"Morning Joe,\" Pelosi gave an extremely peculiar answer when asked about current calls for Joe Biden to step down. The president has been besieged by accusations about his mental competence after a disastrous debate performance in late June.\n\nPerhaps Pelosi was just exhibiting some of her own senility, but from her answer, it sure sounded like something was happening behind the scenes.\n\nLEMIRE: So Madam Speaker, you just went through the president's record, but let me ask you about the current moment. Does he have your support to be the head of the Democratic ticket?\n\nPELOSI: As long as the president has, it's up to the president to decide if he is going to run. We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short. The, I think the overwhelming support of the caucus, it's not for me to say, I'm not the head of the cause anymore, but he's beloved, he is respected, and people want him to make that decision, not me.\n\nLEMIRE: He has said, he has made the decision. He has said firmly this week that he is going to run. Do you want him to run?\n\nPELOSI: I want him to do whatever he decides to do, and that's the way it is. Whatever he decides, we go with. I think it's really important, and I would hope everyone would join in, to let him deal with this NATO conference. This is a very big deal. 30 heads, over 30 heads of state are here. He is the host of it, and that means not just hosting, but that means orchestrating the agenda, and he's doing so magnificently.\n\nAnd I say to everyone, let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell someone privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week.\n\nThat clip is absolutely wild. Pelosi seems unaware that Biden has already pledged to stay in the race multiple times since the debate. Yet, when it's pointed out to her that he's already made that decision, she doubles down, stating that the issue should be picked back up after \"we see how we go this week.\"\n\nSEE: Joe Biden Gives Definitive Answer About His Future, and Democrats Are Going to Need a Stiff Drink\n\nI mean, what? Talk about knee-capping your own candidate. Even Democrats were perplexed by her answer.\n\nThere are a few possibilities here. One is that Pelosi is just old and doesn't comprehend that Biden has already made his decision. Another is that she's not-so-gently nudging the president to reconsider staying in the race, which is astonishing given the tensions within the party. Then there's the possibility that Pelosi does know something we don't and that some kind of surprise move is coming, whether that be Biden dropping out or him being forced out.\n\nRegardless of the reason, everything seems to hinge on the president's \"big boy\" press conference on Friday. As RedState reported, Democrats have set that as the deadline to have Biden out of the race. If he flubs that presser despite how low the bar is already set, the rush to get him out of the race will be overwhelming. Pelosi seems to be hedging her bets, waiting to see how he performs.\n\nThe fact that a major Democrat leader (who has been given the fake title \"Speaker Emerita\") won't just commit to Biden being the nominee at this stage is pretty incredible. The longer this festers, the lower the president's chances of winning re-election become. That Pelosi and others know the stakes are still not willing to speak with confidence about Biden's future is telling. {"uri": "8219226240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:35:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:35:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:35:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/world/americas/pelosi-clooney-urge-biden-to-leave-presidential-race", "title": "Pelosi, Clooney urge Biden to leave presidential race", "body": "More Democrats expressed opposition to President Joe Biden's candidacy in the presidential race, as famous actor George Clooney said Biden should leave the race, amid more calls by Democratic senators and lawmakers amid concerns over his physical and mental capabilities to become president.\n\nThe sudden flurry of grave pronouncements despite Biden's determined insistence he is not leaving the 2024 race put on public display just how unsettled the question remains among prominent Democrats. On Capitol Hill, an eighth House Democrat, Rep. Pat Ryan of New York, publicly asked Biden to step aside.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC rather than declaring Biden should stay in. Though he's said repeatedly that he's made his decision, she said, \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nIt's a crucial moment for the president and his party, as Democrats consider what was once unthinkable - having the incumbent Biden step aside, just weeks before the Democratic National Convention that is on track to nominate him as their candidate for reelection.\n\nBiden is hosting world leaders in Washington for the NATO summit this week with a crowded schedule of formal meetings, sideline chats and long diplomatic dinners. He faces his next public test Thursday when he is scheduled to hold a news conference that many are watching for signs of his abilities.\n\nTo be sure, Biden maintains strong support from key corners of his coalition, particularly the Congressional Black Caucus on Capitol Hill, whose leadership was instrumental in ushering the president to victory in 2020 and is standing by him as the country's best choice to defeat Trump again in 2024.\n\n\"At this moment, the stakes are too high and we have to focus,\" Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota told The Associated Press on Tuesday, saying Democrats are \"losing ground\" the longer they fight over Biden's candidacy. \"Democracy is on the line. Everything we value as Democrats, as a country, is on the line, and we have to stop being distracted.\"\n\nPelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Biden's wounded candidacy, her comments viewed as important for the party's direction as members weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House speaker and proximity to Biden as a trusted longtime ally of his generation, Pelosi is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the president's thinking.\n\nThe lack of a full statement from Pelosi backing Biden's continued campaign is what lawmakers are likely to hear most clearly. Her remarks came moments before actor Clooney, who had just hosted a glitzy Hollywood fundraiser for the president last month, said in a New York Times op-ed that the Biden he saw three weeks ago wasn't the Joe Biden of 2020. \"He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, a Democrat from Colorado, spoke forcefully late Tuesday about the danger of a second Trump presidency and said it's for the president \"to consider\" the options.\n\nStopping just short of calling for Biden to drop out, Bennet said on CNN what he told his colleagues in private - that he believes Trump \"is on track to win this election -- and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House.\"\n\nBennet said, \"It's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country.\"\n\nAnother Democrat, Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, said Wednesday he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden winning the election, which he called existential for the country.\n\n\"We have to reach a conclusion as soon as possible,\" Blumenthal said on CNN.\n\nDemocrats have been reeling over the question of whether to continue backing Biden after his poor showing in the June 27 presidential debate with Trump and his campaign's lackluster response to their pleas that Biden, at 81, show voters he is up for another four-year term.\n\nBiden and his campaign are working more intently now to shore up support, and the president met with labor leaders Wednesday, relying on the unions to help make the case that his record in office matters more than his age.\n\nWith the executive council of the AFL-CIO, America's largest federation of trade unions, Biden told the crowd that even Wall Street was acknowledging the power of unions, as he once again articulated his vision for an economy built \"from the bottom up and middle out.\"\n\n\"I said I'm going to be the most pro-union president in American history,\" Biden told the cheering crowd. \"Well guess what? I am.\"\n\nWhile more House Democrats have publicly called on Biden to end his candidacy, no Senate Democrats have gone that far. Bennet was among three Democratic senators, including Jon Tester of Montana and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who spoke up during a private lunch Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nPelosi of California said Biden \"has been a great president\" who is beloved and respected by House Democrats.\n\nThe Californian said she watched as he delivered a forceful speech at the NATO summit on Tuesday, and recounted his many accomplishments.\n\nWhile foreign leaders are in Washington this week and Biden is on the world stage hosting the event at a critical time in foreign affairs, Pelosi encouraged Democrats \"let's just hold off\" with any announcements about his campaign.\n\n\"Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately but you {"uri": "8218748264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:03:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:03:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:02:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.huffpost.com/entry/nancy-pelosi-biden-reelection_n_668e7b3ee4b0c45d1910dc80", "title": "Nancy Pelosi: 'It's Up To The President' Whether Biden Should Stay In 2024 Race", "body": "Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) answered the question of whether she thought President Joe Biden should continue his troubled run for reelection with a firm declaration: It's up to Biden to decide.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do, and that's the way it is. Whatever he decides, we go with,\" Pelosi said on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe\" program.\n\nBiden has said he thinks the debate over his mental fitness to run that was sparked by his poor debate performance against Donald Trump has run its course and the party should line up in support of him.\n\nBut at least some Democrats on Capitol Hill remain unconvinced. Another House member, Rep. Mikie Sherrill (D-N.J.) called Tuesday for Biden to step back from the race.\n\nWhile Democrats like Sherrill see the danger of Biden losing and simultaneously taking down the chances for Democrats to control either chamber of Congress, others believe Biden still has the best chance to beat Trump again and that public debate over that is unproductive. House and Senate Democrats met separately Tuesday to discuss the impasse, but, in both cases, the meetings were inconclusive.\n\nPelosi's comments give both schools something to point to.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he is going to run. We are all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short,\" she said, seemingly overlooking Biden's comments earlier in the week saying he was staying in the race.\n\nPelosi {"uri": "8219004626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:44:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/pelosi-casts-doubt-on-bidens-white-house-bid/article_c6b27e4b-f223-54d0-8b1e-7e3a64eb8fdb.html", "title": "Pelosi casts doubt on Biden's White House bid", "body": "(The Center Square) - Former House Speaker and long-time Democratic party leader Nancy Pelosi weighed in on whether President Joe Biden should drop out of the race to let another Democrat challenge former President Donald Trump.\n\nPelosi, who is 84 years old, made the comments Wednesday on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe,\" and appeared to suggest there was still a chance Biden could step down, despite the president saying he has no intention of doing so.\n\nWhen directly asked if Biden has her support to be the head of the Democratic ticket, the California Democrat said \"it's up to the president to decide if he is going to run.\"\n\n\"We are all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short,\" Pelosi continued. \"I think overwhelming support of the caucus, it's not for me to say, I'm not the head of the caucus anymore, but he is beloved. He is respected, and people want him to make that decision.\"\n\nWhen pressed further with the point that Biden says he has already made the decision to stay in the race, Pelosi said, \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do, and that's the way it is.\"\n\n\"Whatever he decides, we go with,\" she said.\n\nPelosi said Biden was \"spectacular\" at his NATO summit speech the day before and lauded his record. She emphasized the importance of the NATO summit, which Biden is hosting with dozens of world leaders, and seemed to suggest Biden's decision should come after the NATO summit.\n\nPelosi's comments sparked headlines Wednesday and are particularly important given her senior influence within the party, especially since they seem to contradict Rep. Alexandira Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., another leader in the party, who told reporters Monday that \"the matter is closed.\"\n\nNotably, Biden called in to \"Morning Joe\" earlier this week to shore up support within his own party.\n\nBiden has repeatedly and emphatically said he will remain in the race and told Democrats questioning his candidacy to give it up. Congressional Democrats have continued to pressure Biden out of fear that his weakness will lead to them losing their seats, and any chance at a House or Senate majority, down the ballot.\n\nEnthusiasm about the candidate on the top of the ticket traditionally has a major impact on down ballot races, especially in tight races.\n\nBiden's woes reached a crescendo following the first debate between Biden and Trump two weeks ago, when Biden faltered, stumbled and at times was incoherent in the debate.\n\nImmediately after the debate, Democrats in the party, including elected Democrats, began calling for Biden to step aside, largely aided by left-leaning media.\n\nBiden has pushed back, including sending a letter to Congress attempting to end the discussions, but has so far not succeeded.\n\nThe latest polling shows Trump has a lead over Biden, especially in several key swing states.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": {"uri": "8218797329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:32:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:32:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:31:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/pelosi-noncommittal-biden-run-decides/story?id=111805909", "title": "Pelosi noncommittal on whether she wants Biden to run: 'Whatever he decides to do'", "body": "The Democrat declined to directly answer when asked if Biden has her support.\n\nFormer Speaker Nancy Pelosi, appearing on MSNBC on Wednesday morning, declined to directly answer when asked if President Joe Biden had her support as he seeks reelection amid debate between Democrats on his viability as a candidate.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he is going to run,\" Pelosi told \"Morning Joe\" co-host Jonathan Lemire. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\n\"I think overwhelming support of the caucus -- it's not for me to say, I'm not the head of the caucus anymore -- but, he's beloved, he is respected and people want him to make that decision,\" Pelosi added.\n\nBiden, in a defiant statement to congressional Democrats on Monday, has said he's \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race to the end.\n\nLemire followed up by asking Pelsoi directly, \"Do you want him to run?\"\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi responded. \"And that is the way it is. Whatever he decides to go with.\"\n\n\"I said to everyone -- let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week. But I am very proud of the president,\" Pelosi added.\n\nPelosi led House Democrats for the first two years of the Biden administration, helping pass some of his signature policy achievements such as the bipartisan infrastructure law and gun safety legislation. As a Democratic leader who has worked closely with Biden, Pelosi's thoughts on the president's ability to hold the office could carry a lot of weight in an election year where Biden's rematch with former President Donald Trump is expected to be a close race.\n\nABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos, in Biden's first post-debate television interview, repeatedly pressed the president what he would do if Democratic leaders such as Chuck Schumer, Hakeem Jeffries and Pelosi were to tell him they were worried his presence in the race would impact the party's chances of controlling the House and Senate.\n\nBiden told Stephanopoulos, \"Well, it's, like, they're not gonna do that.\"\n\nSchumer on Tuesday largely declined to engage in questions on Biden's path forward, simply telling reporters multiple times: \"I'm with Joe.\"\n\nJeffries, who earlier this week said he still supported Biden and that his position remained unchanged, huddled behind closed doors on Tuesday with House Democrats to discuss Biden's path forward.\n\nSome described the meeting as \"rough\" and sobering, according to multiple participants. Some described feeling powerless to change course amid Biden's defiance.\n\nAfter the meeting, a seventh House Democrat -- New Jersey's Mikie Sherrill -- publicly called on Biden to exit the race.\n\nSenate Democrats also met for their own conference meeting on Tuesday.\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, during an interview with CNN, said during the meeting he expressed to colleagues his belief that Biden will not defeat Trump this November.\n\n\"Donald Trump is on track, I think to win this election and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House,\" Bennet said. \"For me, this is not a question about polling, it's not a question about politics, it's a moral question about the future of our country and I think it's critically important for us to come to grips with what we face if together we put this country on the path of electing Donald Trump again.\"\n\nMultiple sources confirmed to ABC that Sens. Jon Tester and Sherrod Brown conveyed similar concerns about Biden's ability to win during the meeting. Brown and Tester are both facing difficult reelection campaigns of their own this cycle.\n\nThe Biden campaign pushed back on Bennet's comments, saying the race was always going to be close and is MSNBC on Wednesday.\n\nMs Pelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Mr Biden's candidacy, and her comments will be viewed as important for the party's direction as they weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Republican Donald Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House of Representatives speaker and proximity to Mr Biden as a trusted long-time ally of his generation, she is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the president's thinking.\n\nPressed on whether she personally wants {"uri": "8218829674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:52:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:52:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:51:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/10/pelosi-punts-biden-drop-out-rejects-critics-morning-joe.html", "title": "Pelosi refuses to say she supports Biden as the Democratic nominee", "body": "Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., talks with reporters in the U.S. Capitol about the presidential debate between President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump, on Friday, June 28, 2024.\n\nFormer Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday refused to explicitly endorse President Joe Biden as the party's presidential nominee, and encouraged her colleagues in Congress to pause from making public statements either for or against Biden.\n\n\"Let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" Pelosi said on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe.\"\n\nThe comments were notable because Biden has repeatedly insisted he will not drop out of the race against former President Donald Trump, and said that his decision is final.\n\nPelosi's carefully worded comments suggested that she believes Biden is still deciding whether or not to remain atop the ticket.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he is going to run,\" Pelosi said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nPelosi has long been one of Biden's closest allies in Congress, so her refusal to support Biden as the nominee -- as scores of Democrats already have -- sent ripples across the Capitol Wednesday.\n\nPelosi's remarks came two weeks into Biden's wall-to-wall push to prove to Democrats and voters that his halting, feeble debate performance on Jun 27 was just \"an episode,\" as Pelosi put it last week, and not evidence of \"a condition.\" So far, Biden's public outings have done little to quell Democrats' concerns about his health.\n\n\"I'm not going anywhere,\" Biden said this week in an interview, also on \"Morning Joe.\" \"I absolutely believe that I am the best candidate to beat Donald Trump in 2024.\"\n\nAs a result, this week, Biden's NATO Summit events in Washington come with the added pressure of proving to Democrats that he is fit enough to beat Trump in November and serve a second, four-year term.\n\nThe pressure for Biden to deliver redeeming public performances this week come as voices calling on him to drop out get louder.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sen. Michael Bennet, D-Co., became the first Democratic senator to publicly announce that he does not believe the president can beat Trump, though he did not go so far as to officially call him to exit the race.\n\nOn the other side of Capitol Hill, the pressure has been more openly expressed. Also Tuesday, House Rep. Mikie Sherrill, D-N.J., became the latest in a growing list of House Democrats to officially urge the president to exit the race.\n\nIn private meetings and calls, even more Democratic lawmakers, donors and strategists have expressed concerns about Biden's fitness to mount a grueling campaign and then, should he win in November, to spend another four years in the Oval Office.\n\nIn response to Pelosi's comments, the Biden campaign pointed to a letter the president sent to congressional Democrats on Monday, reiterating his dedication to stay in the race and calling on lawmakers to rally behind him. {"uri": "2024-07-417778043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:59:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:59:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:54:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.rep-am.com/news/2024/07/10/bidens-candidacy-faces-new-peril-as-pelosi-clooney-and-more-democrats-weigh-in/", "title": "Biden's candidacy faces new peril as Pelosi, Clooney and more Democrats weigh in", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden's imperiled re-election campaign hit new trouble Wednesday as House Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi said merely \"it's up to the president to decide\" if he should stay in the race, celebrity donor George Clooney said he should not run and Democratic senators and lawmakers expressed fresh fear about his ability to beat Republican Donald Trump.\n\nThe sudden flurry of grave pronouncements despite Biden's determined insistence he is not leaving the 2024 race put on public display just how unsettled the question remains among prominent Democrats. On Capitol Hill, an eighth House Democrat, Rep. Pat Ryan of New York, publicly asked Biden to step aside.\n\nLamont: Biden should go on the offensive about his health\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi said Wednesday on MSNBC rather than declaring Biden should stay in. Though he's said repeatedly that he's made his decision, she said, \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nIt's a crucial moment for the president and his party, as Democrats consider what was once unthinkable -- having the incumbent Biden step aside, just weeks before the Democratic National Convention that is on track to nominate him as their candidate for reelection.\n\nBiden is hosting world leaders in Washington for the NATO summit this week with a crowded schedule of formal meetings, sideline chats and long diplomatic dinners. He faces his next public test Thursday when he is scheduled to hold a news conference that many are watching for signs of his abilities.\n\nTo be sure, Biden maintains strong support from key corners of his coalition, particularly the Congressional Black Caucus on Capitol Hill, whose leadership was instrumental in ushering the president to victory in 2020 and is standing by him as the country's best choice to defeat Trump again in 2024.\n\n\"At this moment, the stakes are too high and we have to focus,\" Rep. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota told The Associated Press on Tuesday, saying Democrats are \"losing ground\" the longer they fight over Biden's candidacy. \"Democracy is on the line. Everything we value as Democrats, as a country, is on the line, and we have to stop being distracted.\"\n\nPelosi has been widely watched for signals of how top Democrats are thinking about Biden's wounded candidacy, her comments viewed as important for the party's direction as members weigh possible alternatives in the campaign against Trump.\n\nBecause of her powerful position as the former House speaker and proximity to Biden as a trusted longtime ally of his generation, Pelosi is seen as one of the few Democratic leaders who could have influence on the president's thinking.\n\nThe lack of a full statement from Pelosi backing Biden's continued campaign is what lawmakers are likely to hear most clearly. Her remarks came moments before actor Clooney, who had just hosted a glitzy Hollywood fundraiser for the president last month, said in a New York Times op-ed that the Biden he saw three weeks ago wasn't the Joe Biden of 2020. \"He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nSen. Michael Bennet, a Democrat from Colorado, spoke forcefully late Tuesday about the danger of a second Trump presidency and said it's for the president \"to consider\" the options.\n\nStopping just short of calling for Biden to drop out, Bennet said on CNN what he told his colleagues in private - that he believes Trump \"is on track to win this election -- and maybe win it by a landslide and take with him the Senate and the House.\"\n\nBennet said, \"It's not a question about politics. It's a moral question about the future of our country.\"\n\nAnother Democrat, Sen. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, said Wednesday he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden winning the election, which he called existential for the country.\n\n\"We have to reach a conclusion as soon {"uri": "2024-07-417545546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:12:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:12:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:53:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/nancy-pelosi-suggests-joe-biden-135358679.html", "title": "Nancy Pelosi suggests Joe Biden should reconsider staying in US presidential race", "body": "Nancy Pelosi suggests Joe Biden should reconsider staying in US presidential race\n\nRozina Sabur\n\n10 July 2024 at 3:53 pm\n\nNancy Pelosi ignored Joe Biden's claims that he was staying in the race to be the Democrats' presidential candidate in 2024 and said time was \"running short\" for him to make that decision.\n\nThe former Speaker of the House has not endorsed the US President as the party's best option for beyond his current term. Ms Pelosi told Mr Biden's favourite morning news show, MSNBC's Morning Joe, that \"it's up to the President to decide if he is going to run. We're all encouraging him to make that decision. Because time is running short.\"\n\nAs one of the Democrats' most senior figures, her comments are likely to bolster calls from within the party for Mr Biden to step aside.\n\nThe 81-year-old President has repeatedly insisted he will seek a second term in November's White House race, declaring himself the best candidate to beat Donald Trump.\n\nBut Ms Pelosi ignored that claim when asked on MSNBC if Mr Biden had her support to top the Democratic ticket. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"And that's the way it is. Whatever he decides we go with.\"\n\nShe added that Mr Biden was \"beloved\" by the party, but declined to endorse his 2024 bid.\n\nHer public intervention may galvanise other prominent Democrats, who view Ms Pelosi as one of the few figures who could convince Mr Biden against seeking re-election.\n\nMany in the party have privately, and some publicly, voiced concerns over Mr Biden's ability to win re-election following an embarrassing debate performance in which he struggled to deliver coherent sentences.\n\nMichael Bennet, a Democratic senator for Colorado, has warned that Republicans could take the White House, the House and the Senate in a \"landslide\" win if Mr Biden stayed in the race. \"It's critically important for us to come to grips with what we face, if together, we put this country on the path of electing Donald Trump again,\" he told CNN.\n\nDemocrats are closely watching Mr Biden's performance at this week's Nato summit, where he is due to hold a rare solo press conference on Thursday in a bid to prove his ability to serve another four years.\n\nMs Pelosi said the President and his party should focus on the Nato conference before coming to a decision on Mr Biden's future. \"Let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately... but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she told MSNBC.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", {"uri": "8218961860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:17:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:17:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:15:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/nancy-pelosi-politely-suggests-biden-change-course.html", "title": "Pelosi: You Sure You Want to Stay in, Joe?", "body": "During a Wednesday morning appearance on Morning Joe, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi offered praise for President Joe Biden, who is in the middle of an intraparty debate over the viability of his candidacy. But the California congresswoman notably stopped short of saying she thought Biden should continue his reelection bid, instead offering a decidedly mixed, yet clear, message that he should reconsider.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he's going to run. We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short,\" Pelosi said.\n\nShe continued, \"He is beloved. He is respected. And people want him to make that decision, not me.\"\n\nBiden made it clear earlier this week that he has, in fact, made his decision, sending a letter to congressional Democrats stating that he has no plans of dropping out and that he's the strongest possible candidate to run against Donald Trump. The president followed up his statement by calling in to Morning Joe -- which Pelosi knows he watches religiously -- daring his critics to challenge him at the Democratic National Convention in August.\n\nPelosi also suggested that members of the party wait to address the question of Biden's fitness while the eyes of the world are on the president as he hosts the NATO Summit in Washington, D.C., adding that he's doing so \"magnificently.\" \"Let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said.\n\nWhen pressed on whether she wants Biden to run, Pelosi once again deferred to the president. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do and that's the way it is. Whatever he decides, we go with,\" she said.\n\nPelosi's comments mark a strong contrast from other leaders in the Democratic Party, who have offered either full-throated or medium-throated support of Biden. On Monday, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries told reporters that he is still backing the president. \"I made clear publicly the day after the debate that I support President Joe Biden and the Democratic ticket. My position has not changed,\" he said. Since Biden's disastrous debate performance last month, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer has repeated one consistent refrain when asked whether he should step aside: \"I'm with Joe.\"\n\nJim Clyburn, the South Carolina congressman and former House majority whip whose 2020 endorsement played a key role in Biden's eventual win, has also stood by the president among the calls by some party members for him to drop out. \"We're riding with Biden,\" he said following the House Democrats caucus meeting Tuesday morning.\n\nHowever, Pelosi's remarks demonstrate that there's still some uneasiness within the Democratic Party despite the many members who have voiced their support of Biden in recent days. In an interview with CNN on Tuesday, Senator Michael Bennet confirmed that he said in a closed-door caucus meeting that Biden will likely lose in November.\n\n\"Donald Trump is on track, I think, to win this election, and maybe win it by a landslide, and take with him the Senate and the House,\" he said. \"So for me, this isn't a question about polling. {"uri": "8218935277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:02:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:02:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:58:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/nancy-pelosi-dodges-morning-joe-145402446.html", "title": "Nancy Pelosi Dodges 'Morning Joe' Question on Biden Candidacy, Says It's 'Up to the President' to Decide", "body": "Former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi avoided offering her personal opinion of whether President Joe Biden should step down or run for reelection during an appearance on \"Morning Joe\" on Wednesday, but in doing so she also avoided putting her full-throated support behind his reelection bid.\n\nWhen asked point blank if Biden has her support to be the head of the Democratic ticket, Pelosi replied, \"It's up to the president to decide if he's going to run. We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\" The former Speaker added that Biden is \"beloved\" and \"respected\" and said \"people want him to make that decision.\"\n\nOf course, Biden has made clear that he's already made his decision, issuing a statement earlier this week that he's not dropping out of the race. He's running. MSNBC host Jonathan Lemire followed up by pointing this out to Pelosi, asking again if she wants him to run, to which the former Speaker replied, \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do, and that's the way it is. Whatever he decides, we go with.\"\n\nEarlier in the interview, \"Morning Joe\" cohost Mika Brzezinski confronted Pelosi with the growing calls from Democrats for Biden to drop out of the race in the wake of his disastrous debate performance and subpar ABC News interview with George Stephanopoulos.\n\n\"That's one version of the story,\" Pelosi replied. \"What I do want to say is that yesterday I was honored to be present at the president's speech at NATO, he was absolutely spectacular. He was received over and over again with ovations for what he had to say and the force with which he said it.\"\n\nThe president has faced calls from both lawmakers and prominent donors to drop out of the race following the debate, and to make way for a more viable candidate to defeat Donald Trump. Despite this, Biden remains steadfast that he's running, sending a letter to congressional Democrats on Monday.\n\n\"I have heard the concerns that people have -- their good faith fears and worries about what is at stake in this election. {"uri": "8219202190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:14:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:14:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:14:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/world/americas/nancy-pelosi-says-joe-biden-who-insists-hell-run-must-make-decision-on-2024-campaign-1.1720634824616", "title": "Nancy Pelosi says Joe Biden, who insists he'll run, must make decision on 2024 campaign", "body": "Washington: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi declined to support President Joe Biden's intention to seek reelection, saying instead that it remains his decision to make - the latest signal of unease among Democrats over the incumbent's age and ability to defeat Republican Donald Trump in November.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he's going to run,\" Pelosi said on MSNBC's Morning Joe on Wednesday. \"We are all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" Pelosi, one of the most influential figures in the Democratic Party, said when pressed on whether she wants him to stay in the race.\n\nBiden began the week by flatly telling members of Congress that he intends to remain the party nominee, as doubts swirl in the aftermath of his calamitous debate performance. He's seeking to quell a rebellion from lawmakers, donors and other prominent figures in the party who have called for him to step aside and allow a new candidate to take on Trump.\n\nread more Actor, Democratic donor George Clooney urges Biden to end campaign NATO summit: Biden shores up support but doubts remain among some Democrats White House dodges questions over Parkinson's doctor, says Biden is fine Fresh round of hazards: This week absolutely critical for Biden, says Senator Chris Murphy\n\nBiden reiterated his intention to remain in the race again hours after Pelosi's comments, telling labour leaders gathered in Washington he was \"staying\" atop the ticket.\n\nThe outcry, though, extended to one of the party's biggest celebrity supporters and donors, George Clooney, who called for a new nominee Wednesday just a few weeks after he attended a fundraiser with Biden.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president,\" Clooney wrote in a New York Times op-ed, adding that Biden, at the fundraiser, was \"the same man we all witnessed at the debate.\"\n\nClooney said he had spoken to senators, members of the House, and governors about his concern - and that \"every single one\" believed Democrats would lose control of both chambers of Congress.\n\n'Hold off'\n\nPelosi urged lawmakers not to publicly air their concerns about the president until the NATO summit being held in Washington concludes. Biden is expected to hold a high-stakes news conference Thursday afternoon, while foreign allies attending the event are closely watching the US president.\n\n\"I said to everyone, let's just hold off - whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" Pelosi said.\n\nThe poor debate performance from Biden, 81, raised worried about the fitness and mental acuity of the already oldest US president in history to defeat Trump and serve another four-year term. Those worries have been amplified by fears that a weak presidential candidate at the top of the ticket could wreck Democratic hopes of retaking the House and holding onto Senate control.\n\nThe issue even came up as Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell testified on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. Powell said that while he had not met with Biden for years, he had not seen cognitive decline in the president.\n\nA New York Times/Siena College poll after the debate found Trump ahead of Biden by six percentage points and Democratic worries intensified on Tuesday after the Cook Political Report updated their Electoral College analysis to show a more favourable map for the Republican candidate.\n\nStill, many prominent Democrats have been reluctant to outright call on Biden to exit the race. In the hours after her MSNBC comments, Pelosi told CBS News she had not intended to signal Biden \"should reconsider his decision.\"\n\nShe subsequently released a statement saying Democrats \"must turn our attention to why this race is so important: Donald Trump would be a disaster for our country and our democracy.\"\n\nJim Clyburn, a South Carolina congressman who has long championed Biden in Democratic politics, said he would ask Pelosi what she meant by her remarks.\n\n\"I'm still riding with Biden,\" he added.\n\nNew defection\n\nBut Pelosi's comments were followed by another Democratic lawmaker - Pat Ryan, a congressman from New York - calling on Biden to step aside.\n\n\"I'd be doing a grave disservice if I said he was the best candidate to serve this fall,\" Ryan told the New York Times. \"I'm asking Joe Biden to step aside in the upcoming election and deliver on the promise to be a bridge to a new generation of leaders.\"\n\nOther prominent Democratic lawmakers simply echoed Pelosi's tepid support. Katherine Clark, the No. 2 House Democrat, said Biden is the party's nominee but like Pelosi did not explicitly stand behind him.\n\n\"As always this decision is up to the president,\" Clark said.\n\nRitchie Torres, a Democratic congressman from New York, said \"there must be a serious reckoning with the down-ballot effect of whomever we nominate,\" nodding to the risk that an unpopular Biden could drag down House and Senate candidates.\n\n\"What matters is not how we feel but what the numbers tell us,\" Torres said in a written statement Wednesday.\n\nKate Bedingfield, who was Biden's deputy campaign manager in 2020, said the president's current team needed to demonstrate that the president still has a viable path to victory.\n\n\"If they have data that supports the path to victory that they see, they should put it out there now,\" Bedingfield wrote on X.", "source": {"uri": "gulfnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GULF NEWS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417514655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:44:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:44:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.wsj.com/politics/elections/nancy-pelosi-says-biden-still-has-a-decision-to-make-on-running-6647ed1f", "title": "Nancy Pelosi Says Biden Still Has a Decision to Make on Running", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Former House Speaker Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) indicated President Biden's political fate remained an open question, while pressing colleagues to hold off on any judgments until after this week's North Atlantic Treaty Organization conference concludes.\n\n\"It's up to the president to decide if he's going to run,\" Pelosi said in an interview on MSNBC's \"Morning Joe.\" \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision, because time is running short.\"\n\nBiden has said repeatedly and forcefully in the past week that he plans to stay in the race against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump, in the face of mounting questions about whether he can win and serve another term. With her comments, Pelosi is joining many Democrats who, while stopping short of saying he should leave, have signaled he should continue to think about his decision to stay in the race. To date, only seven House Democrats, and no senators, have called on him to step aside.\n\n\"I've said to everyone, 'let's just hold off,'\" Pelosi said. \"Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week.\" She also praised the president, saying he \"is beloved, he is respected\" by Democratic colleagues.\n\nPelosi worked closely with Biden during his first two years in office. While no longer leading the party, she remains a prominent and influential figure.\n\nDemocrats on Capitol Hill discussed the president's candidacy in closed-door caucus meetings on Tuesday, and some members remain unconvinced that Biden should stay in the race. Many lawmakers are increasingly doubtful he can win, and fear he could drag House and Senate candidates down with him. Two people familiar with internal House Democratic discussions said they expected the number of people calling for Biden to step down to soon increase.\n\nThere is no clear means of replacing Biden atop the ticket unless he decides to drop out of the race, given that he controls almost all of the party's delegates thanks to sweeping the primaries earlier this year. If he were to step aside, Democrats would have to quickly coalesce around a new nominee, also a tall order.\n\n\"Right now, President Biden is the nominee, and we support the Democratic nominee that will beat Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar (D., Calif.), a member of party leadership, said Tuesday. \"Let's see. Let's see the press conference. Let's see the campaign stops. Let's see all of this, because all of it is going to be necessary.\"\n\nSen. Michael Bennet (D., Colo.) told colleagues in their meeting that he didn't think Biden would prevail this fall. Speaking to CNN, he said he thinks Trump is on track to \"maybe win it by a landslide, and take with him the Senate and the House.\" But he declined to say Biden should step aside.\n\nSome members skeptical of the president's candidacy spoke at caucus meetings on Tuesday, including Rep. Seth Moulton (D., Mass.), who has called for Biden to step aside.\n\n\"Everyone was listening very carefully to the variety of positions in the room, and it's exactly the kind of debate and discussion that we should be having as a party,\" Moulton told reporters. \"This is what democracy is about.\"\n\nPelosi, who worked with Biden on major legislation including his infrastructure law and sweeping climate package as speaker, has been a steadfast supporter of the president. She noted that he has a jam-packed schedule this week as world leaders descend on Washington for the NATO summit.\n\nBiden spoke to NATO leaders Tuesday night for the summit's opening ceremony. It was the latest in a string of appearances under heavy scrutiny from the public, as the president works to convince voters that he can deliver a strong message after his disastrous debate performance in June.\n\nPelosi heaped praise on Biden for the address. \"He was absolutely spectacular,\" she said.\n\nThe president has received notable backing from members of the Congressional Black Caucus, the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and progressives, as well as longtime allies who point to his legislative accomplishments during his first term in office.\n\n\"He has to make a decision,\" said Rep. Julia Brownley (D., Calif.). \"You could say he's already made a decision. Is that a final decision? If it is, then I don't think there's another alternative.\"\n\nWrite to Owen Tucker-Smith at Owen.Tucker-Smith@wsj.com", "source": {"uri": "wsj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Wall Street
